Package io.github.ai4ci.abm.inhost

Interface InHostPhenomenologicalState.ExposureModel

All Superinterfaces:
Serializable
Enclosing interface:
InHostPhenomenologicalState
@Immutable public static interface InHostPhenomenologicalState.ExposureModel extends Serializable
Represents a single exposure event (infection or vaccination) that contributes to viral load and immune response.

Each exposure is characterized by:

  • Timing: when it occurred,
  • Dose: normalized exposure level,
  • Immune context: immune activity at time of exposure,
  • Temporal offsets: shifts in the growth and decay phases of the response.

The viral load from an exposure at time \( t \) is: \[ v_e(t) = f(t - t_e + g_e; r_g, s_g) \cdot \left(1 - f(t - t_e + d_e; r_d, s_d)\right) \] where:

  • \( t_e \): exposure time,
  • \( g_e \): growth phase offset,
  • \( d_e \): decay phase offset,
  • \( f(x; r, s) = \frac{1}{1 + \exp(-r(x - s))} \): logistic function,
  • \( r_g, s_g \): growth rate and midpoint,
  • \( r_d, s_d \): decay rate and midpoint.

The immune response is modeled similarly but without the decay modulation.

    MIN_IMMUNE_ACTIVITY
    Minimum immune activity threshold below which an exposure is considered irrelevant for future immune boosting.

  • Method Details

    • createExposure

      static InHostPhenomenologicalState.ExposureModel createExposure(double exposure, double immuneActivity, InHostPhenomenologicalState.BiPhasicLogistic viralLoad, int time)
      Factory method to create a new exposure with calibrated temporal offsets.

      The growth offset \( g_e \) is computed so that the viral load at time 0 of the exposure matches the scaled dose: \[ g_e = t_g - \frac{1}{r_g} \log\left(\frac{1 - v_0}{v_0}\right) \] where \( v_0 = \text{dose} \cdot \text{unit} \), and \( \text{unit} = f(0; r_g, s_g) \).

      The decay offset \( d_e \) is set to ensure the immune activity at exposure matches the current level (but never shifted backward): \[ d_e = \max\left(0, t_d - \frac{1}{r_d} \log\left(\frac{1 - I(t)}{I(t)}\right)\right) \]

      Parameters:
      exposure - normalized exposure dose (relative to infectious dose)
      immuneActivity - current immune activity at time of exposure
      viralLoad - model defining the shape of the response
      time - time of exposure
      Returns:
      a new exposure model with calibrated offsets

    • getDecayOffset

      double getDecayOffset()
      Returns the temporal offset applied to the decay phase of the response curve. This offset shifts the decay curve to align with the immune activity at exposure.
      Returns:
      the decay phase offset

    • getExposureImmuneActivity

      default double getExposureImmuneActivity(int time, InHostPhenomenologicalState.BiPhasicLogistic model)
      Computes the immune activity contribution of this exposure at a given time.

      If \( t \leq t_e \), returns 0. Otherwise: \[ i_e(t) = f(t - t_e; r_g, s_g) \cdot \left(1 - f(t - t_e; r_d, s_d)\right) \] This represents the unadjusted immune trajectory initiated by the exposure.

      Parameters:
      time - the current time step
      model - the biphasic logistic model for immune dynamics
      Returns:
      the immune activity from this exposure at the given time

    • getExposureTime

      int getExposureTime()
      Returns the time step at which this exposure occurred.
      Returns:
      the time of exposure

    • getExposureViralLoad

      default double getExposureViralLoad(int time, InHostPhenomenologicalState.BiPhasicLogistic model)
      Computes the viral load contribution of this exposure at a given time.

      If \( t \leq t_e \), returns 0. Otherwise: \[ v_e(t) = f(t - t_e + g_e; r_g, s_g) \cdot \left(1 - f(t - t_e + d_e; r_d, s_d)\right) \] This biphasic form models rapid viral growth followed by immune-mediated clearance.

      Parameters:
      time - the current time step
      model - the biphasic logistic model defining growth and decay dynamics
      Returns:
      the viral load from this exposure at the given time

    • getGrowthOffset

      double getGrowthOffset()
      Returns the temporal offset applied to the growth phase of the response curve. This offset shifts the growth curve in time to match the initial viral load at exposure.
      Returns:
      the growth phase offset

    • getImmuneActivityAtExposure

      double getImmuneActivityAtExposure()
      Returns the immune activity at the time of exposure. This value is used to calibrate the decay offset of the response curve.
      Returns:
      the immune activity at the time of exposure

    • getNormalisedExposure

      double getNormalisedExposure()
      Returns the normalized exposure dose for this event.
      Returns:
      the normalized exposure level (relative to infectious dose)

    • isIrrelevant

      default boolean isIrrelevant(int time, InHostPhenomenologicalState.BiPhasicLogistic model)
      Determines whether this exposure is no longer relevant for immune boosting.

      An exposure is considered irrelevant if the time since exposure exceeds the point at which the immune response has waned below 1% of its peak. This is computed using the inverse logistic function to find the time at which the decay phase falls below the threshold, and comparing it to the current time.

      Parameters:
      time - the current time step
      model - the biphasic logistic model for immune dynamics
      Returns:
      true if this exposure is irrelevant for future immune boosting, false otherwise
